title: Matthew Chapter 11 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Matthew chapter 11 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Matthew Chapter 11 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Matthew Chapter 11.

questions.question: Who did Jesus send two disciples to when John was in prison?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: John, hearing about Jesus' works from prison, sent two of his disciples to Jesus (Matthew 11:2).

questions.question: What did John the Baptist ask Jesus through his disciples?
options: Are you the one who should come, or do we look for another?
questions.correctAnswer: Are you the one who should come, or do we look for another?
questions.explanation: John asked Jesus if He was the expected one or if they should look for another (Matthew 11:3).

questions.question: Which of these miracles did Jesus mention to John’s disciples as evidence?
questions.correctAnswer: Blind receive sight
questions.explanation: Jesus told John’s disciples that the blind receive sight among other miracles (Matthew 11:5).

questions.question: How did Jesus describe John the Baptist in comparison to others born of women?
questions.correctAnswer: The greatest
questions.explanation: Jesus said John the Baptist was the greatest born of women (Matthew 11:11).

questions.question: Who did Jesus say John the Baptist was, if people were willing to receive it?
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah
questions.explanation: Jesus identified John as Elijah who was to come (Matthew 11:14).

questions.question: What did Jesus compare this generation to in Matthew 11:16?
questions.correctAnswer: Children sitting in the markets
questions.explanation: Jesus likened this generation to children sitting in the markets calling to their fellows (Matthew 11:16).

questions.question: What accusation was made against John the Baptist according to Matthew 11:18?
questions.correctAnswer: He hath a devil
questions.explanation: People said John had a devil because he neither ate nor drank (Matthew 11:18).

questions.question: According to Matthew 11:19, what did people say about the Son of Man?
options: He is gluttonous and a winebibber
questions.correctAnswer: He is gluttonous and a winebibber
questions.explanation: People criticized the Son of Man for eating and drinking, calling Him gluttonous and a winebibber (Matthew 11:19).

questions.question: Which cities did Jesus pronounce woes upon for not repenting?
questions.correctAnswer: Chorazin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum
questions.explanation: Jesus pronounced woes on Chorazin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum for their lack of repentance (Matthew 11:20-23).

questions.question: What did Jesus say about the kingdom of heaven in Matthew 11:12?
options: It suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force
It is only for the poor
questions.correctAnswer: It suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force
questions.explanation: Jesus described the kingdom of heaven as suffering violence and being taken by force (Matthew 11:12).

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said that no one knows the Father except Himself and those to whom He reveals Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus stated that no man knows the Father except the Son and those the Son reveals Him to (Matthew 11:27).

questions.question: True or False: Jesus invited all who labor and are heavy laden to come to Him for rest.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus invited those who labor and are burdened to come to Him for rest (Matthew 11:28).

questions.question: True or False: Jesus said His yoke is heavy and His burden is hard to bear.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jesus said His yoke is easy and His burden is light (Matthew 11:30).

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'Take my yoke upon you, and learn of me; for I am meek and ______ in heart.'
questions.correctAnswer: lowly
questions.explanation: Jesus describes Himself as meek and lowly in heart in Matthew 11:29.

questions.question: How did Jesus describe those who wear soft clothing in Matthew 11:8?
questions.correctAnswer: They are in kings' houses
questions.explanation: Jesus said those who wear soft clothing are in kings' houses (Matthew 11:8).

medium.title: Matthew Chapter 11 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Matthew Chapter 11 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt about Jesus' identity during difficult times. Based on Matthew 11, what biblical truth would you share to encourage their faith?
options: Jesus' miracles prove He is the Messiah
Doubt is a sign of weak faith
John the Baptist was mistaken about Jesus
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus' miracles prove He is the Messiah
questions.explanation: Jesus tells John's disciples to observe the miracles happening around them—blind receive sight, lame walk, lepers are cleansed, deaf hear, dead raised, and the gospel preached to the poor—which confirm His identity as the Messiah (Matthew 11:4-5). This encourages faith amid doubt.

questions.question: How does Matthew 11 teach us about humility in leadership through the example of John the Baptist?
options: John recognized he was preparing the way for someone greater
John claimed to be the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: John recognized he was preparing the way for someone greater
questions.explanation: John is described as the messenger preparing the way for Jesus (Matthew 11:10), and Jesus says no one born of women is greater than John, yet even the least in the kingdom is greater, illustrating humility in recognizing God's greater plan (Matthew 11:11).

questions.question: A believer feels discouraged because others criticize their godly lifestyle. Based on Matthew 11, what biblical principle can help them persevere?
options: Wisdom is justified by her children
Criticism means you are doing wrong
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom is justified by her children
questions.explanation: Jesus points out that although John was called demon-possessed and He was called a glutton and drunkard, wisdom is justified by her children—meaning the results and fruits of godly living vindicate it despite criticism (Matthew 11:18-19).

questions.question: How does Jesus' invitation in Matthew 11:28-30 teach us about trusting God in times of exhaustion and stress?
options: Come to Jesus for rest and take His yoke upon you
Work harder to solve your problems alone
Ignore your burdens and keep going
questions.correctAnswer: Come to Jesus for rest and take His yoke upon you
questions.explanation: Jesus invites those who labor and are heavy laden to come to Him for rest, learning from His meek and lowly heart, promising an easy yoke and light burden, teaching trust and dependence on Him (Matthew 11:28-30).

questions.question: What does Matthew 11 teach us about responding to God's message when people reject both repentance and celebration?
options: The generation is like children who neither dance nor mourn
They only reject celebration, not repentance
questions.correctAnswer: The generation is like children who neither dance nor mourn
questions.explanation: Jesus compares the generation to children calling to their fellows, but refusing to respond to either joyful or sorrowful calls, illustrating stubbornness and rejection of God's ways (Matthew 11:16-17).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to pride because of their spiritual knowledge. According to Matthew 11, what biblical truth should guide their attitude?
options: God reveals His truths to those with childlike humility, not just the wise
Only the learned can understand God's will
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals His truths to those with childlike humility, not just the wise
questions.explanation: Jesus thanks the Father for hiding truths from the wise and prudent and revealing them to babes, emphasizing humility and simple faith over intellectual pride (Matthew 11:25-26).

questions.question: How does Matthew 11 instruct believers about the importance of repentance in response to witnessing God's mighty works?
options: Cities that witnessed miracles but did not repent face greater judgment
Repentance is optional after seeing miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Cities that witnessed miracles but did not repent face greater judgment
questions.explanation: Jesus reproves Chorazin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum for not repenting despite mighty works done there, declaring judgment will be more tolerable for other cities that repented at fewer signs (Matthew 11:20-24).

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 11, John the Baptist lived a life of indulgence and luxury.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: John came neither eating nor drinking in the usual way, living a life of austerity, which led some to accuse him of having a demon (Matthew 11:18).

questions.question: True or False: Jesus states that no one knows the Father except the Son and those to whom the Son reveals Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jesus declares that no one knows the Father except the Son, and those to whom the Son will reveal Him, highlighting the unique relationship and revelation through Christ (Matthew 11:27).

questions.question: Based on Matthew 11, how should believers respond when facing criticism for their association with sinners or outcasts?
options: Jesus befriended sinners to show God's love and wisdom
Only associate with the religious elite
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus befriended sinners to show God's love and wisdom
questions.explanation: Jesus came eating and drinking, being called a glutton and friend of sinners, showing compassion and wisdom in reaching out to all, encouraging believers to reflect this love despite criticism (Matthew 11:19).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jesus invites all who ______ and are heavy laden to come to Him for rest.
questions.correctAnswer: labor
questions.explanation: Jesus invites those who labor and are heavy laden to come to Him for rest, emphasizing His care for the burdened and weary (Matthew 11:28).

questions.question: How does Matthew 11 illustrate the nature of spiritual advancement in the kingdom of heaven?
options: Even the least in the kingdom is greater than John the Baptist
John the Baptist is the greatest in the kingdom
Spiritual status is based on birthright
The kingdom belongs only to prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Even the least in the kingdom is greater than John the Baptist
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches that although John the Baptist is the greatest born of women, the least in the kingdom of heaven is greater, showing the surpassing value of the kingdom and new covenant blessings (Matthew 11:11).

questions.question: A believer is questioning the effectiveness of God's kingdom in a hostile world. According to Matthew 11, what reality should they understand about the kingdom's progress?
options: The kingdom suffers violence and is taken by force
The kingdom is hidden and inactive
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom suffers violence and is taken by force
questions.explanation: Jesus states that from John's time until now, the kingdom of heaven suffers violence and the violent take it by force, indicating spiritual conflict and perseverance in advancing God's reign (Matthew 11:12).

questions.question: What does Matthew 11 teach about God's sovereign revelation and human knowledge?
options: No one knows the Father except the Son and those He reveals to
All people naturally know God equally
Knowledge of God depends on education
God reveals Himself only through nature
questions.correctAnswer: No one knows the Father except the Son and those He reveals to
questions.explanation: Jesus says all things are delivered to Him by the Father, and only the Son knows the Father fully, revealing Him to chosen people, emphasizing divine revelation over human effort (Matthew 11:27).

questions.question: How does Matthew 11 encourage believers to handle burdens in daily life?
options: Take Jesus' yoke upon you and learn from Him for rest
Seek relief only through worldly means
questions.correctAnswer: Take Jesus' yoke upon you and learn from Him for rest
questions.explanation: Jesus invites believers to take His yoke and learn from His meekness and lowliness, promising rest for their souls and a light burden, teaching reliance and humility in daily challenges (Matthew 11:29-30).

hard.title: Matthew Chapter 11 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Matthew Chapter 11.

questions.question: In Matthew 11:4-5, Jesus lists miracles as evidence of His identity. Which Old Testament prophecy do these miracles fulfill?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 35:5-6
questions.explanation: Jesus' description of the blind seeing, lame walking, lepers cleansed, deaf hearing, the dead raised, and the poor receiving the gospel directly alludes to Isaiah 35:5-6, fulfilling messianic prophecy.

questions.question: Matthew 11:7-10 uses a series of rhetorical questions about John the Baptist's identity. Which literary device is most prominent in this passage?
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical questioning
questions.explanation: Jesus employs rhetorical questions to challenge the crowd’s expectations and clarify John’s prophetic role, emphasizing his importance through a questioning style.

questions.question: In Matthew 11:11, Jesus states that 'he that is least in the kingdom of heaven is greater than John.' What theological theme does this statement highlight?
options: The superiority of the new covenant over the old covenant
The primacy of the law over grace
The role of angels in the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The superiority of the new covenant over the old covenant
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the transition from the old covenant represented by John the Baptist to the new covenant of the kingdom of heaven, indicating greater privilege and knowledge under the new covenant.

questions.question: What does Matthew 11:12 mean when it says 'the kingdom of heaven suffereth violence, and the violent take it by force'?
options: The kingdom advances despite opposition through determined effort
The kingdom is only for the strong
The kingdom is exclusive to a violent elite
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom advances despite opposition through determined effort
questions.explanation: The phrase uses metaphorical language to describe the intense spiritual struggle and fervor involved in entering the kingdom, emphasizing perseverance and zeal.

questions.question: Matthew 11:14 identifies John the Baptist with Elias (Elijah). How does this typology enhance understanding of John's role?
options: It connects John as the forerunner to the Messiah, fulfilling Malachi's prophecy
It equates John with Elijah’s miracles
It suggests John will return after death
questions.correctAnswer: It connects John as the forerunner to the Messiah, fulfilling Malachi's prophecy
questions.explanation: By calling John 'Elias,' Jesus links him to the prophecy in Malachi 4:5 about Elijah returning to prepare the way for the Messiah, confirming John’s role as the messenger.

questions.question: In Matthew 11:16-17, Jesus compares the generation to children who neither dance nor mourn. What cultural practice is He alluding to?
options: Children’s games in marketplaces involving calls to dance or mourn
questions.correctAnswer: Funerary lamentations and wedding celebrations
questions.explanation: Jesus uses the metaphor of children calling for dancing (weddings) and mourning (funerals), highlighting the generation’s unresponsiveness to both John’s austerity and Jesus’ fellowship.

questions.question: Matthew 11:18-19 contrasts John the Baptist and Jesus in terms of lifestyle and public perception. Which Greek word used for 'gluttonous' or 'winebibber' underscores Jesus' association with sinners?
questions.correctAnswer: κρασοπότης (krasopotēs) - wine drinker
questions.explanation: The term 'κρασοπότης' highlights Jesus’ association with common social drinkers and sinners, contrasting with John’s asceticism and emphasizing the wisdom justified by its outcomes.

questions.question: Jesus pronounces woes on Chorazin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum in Matthew 11:20-24. What historical or cultural significance do these cities have in the context of Jesus’ ministry?
options: They were centers of Jesus’ miracles yet showed no repentance
They were major trade hubs for Gentiles
They were known for Pharisaic schools
questions.correctAnswer: They were centers of Jesus’ miracles yet showed no repentance
questions.explanation: These cities witnessed many of Jesus' mighty works but failed to repent, leading to severe warnings comparing them unfavorably to notorious cities known for sinfulness like Tyre, Sidon, and Sodom.

questions.question: The prayer of thanksgiving in Matthew 11:25-26 shows Jesus thanking the Father for revealing truths to 'babes' rather than 'the wise and prudent.' What theme does this reflect in biblical theology?
options: Divine revelation favors humility and childlike faith
Wisdom is based on social status
Revelation is based on strict law observance
questions.correctAnswer: Divine revelation favors humility and childlike faith
questions.explanation: The passage emphasizes that God chooses to reveal His kingdom’s mysteries to those with humility and simplicity rather than to those confident in their own wisdom, consistent with other scriptures like 1 Corinthians 1:27.

questions.question: Matthew 11:27 speaks of unique mutual knowledge between the Father and the Son. Which theological doctrine is primarily expressed here?
questions.correctAnswer: The doctrine of the Trinity
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the intimate and exclusive knowledge shared between Father and Son, foundational to Trinitarian theology emphasizing their distinct personhood yet unity.

questions.question: In Matthew 11:28-30, Jesus invites all who labor and are heavy laden to take His yoke. What is the significance of the 'yoke' metaphor in the Jewish cultural and religious context?
options: A symbol of submission to God's teaching and rest from legalistic burdens
A tool for agricultural labor only
questions.correctAnswer: A symbol of submission to God's teaching and rest from legalistic burdens
questions.explanation: The yoke metaphor conveys the idea of accepting Jesus’ guidance, which contrasts with the heavy burdens of the Pharisaic law, offering spiritual rest and ease.

questions.question: True or False: According to Matthew 11:3, John the Baptist in prison sent two of his disciples to ask Jesus if He was the expected Messiah or if they should wait for another.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Matthew 11:2-3 explicitly states that John, while imprisoned, sent two disciples to Jesus asking if He was the one to come or if they should expect another.

questions.question: How does Matthew 11:6 characterize those who are not offended by Jesus’ works and words?
questions.correctAnswer: They are blessed
questions.explanation: Verse 6 declares a blessing upon anyone who is not scandalized or offended by Jesus, highlighting the value of faith despite challenges.

questions.question: Matthew 11:13 states that 'all the prophets and the law prophesied until John.' What does this imply about John the Baptist's role in salvation history?
options: He marks the culmination and transition point from prophecy to fulfillment
He is the last prophet before the exile
He is the first priest of the new covenant
questions.correctAnswer: He marks the culmination and transition point from prophecy to fulfillment
questions.explanation: This verse indicates that John the Baptist serves as the final prophet who prepares for the Messiah, representing the closing of the prophetic era.

questions.question: According to Matthew 11:23-24, what consequence is pronounced on Capernaum due to its unrepentance despite witnessing mighty works?
options: It will be brought down to hell
It will become a thriving city
It will be rebuilt in glory
questions.correctAnswer: It will be brought down to hell
questions.explanation: Jesus warns Capernaum that despite its exalted status, it will face severe judgment for its failure to repent, unlike even Sodom, which would have survived if it had seen such works.

theological.title: Matthew Chapter 11 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Matthew Chapter 11 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What evidence does Jesus give to John’s disciples to confirm He is the Messiah?
options: The blind receive their sight, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and the gospel is preached to the poor
He performed many miracles in Jerusalem
He fasted for 40 days and nights
He descended from the line of King David
questions.correctAnswer: The blind receive their sight, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and the gospel is preached to the poor
questions.explanation: Jesus lists signs of His messianic ministry as fulfillment of Isaiah's prophecy (Isaiah 35:5-6, 61:1), confirming His identity to John (Matthew 11:4-5). This mirrors Old Testament expectations of the Messiah’s works (Luke 7:22; Isaiah 29:18).

questions.question: According to Jesus, who is greater than John the Baptist?
options: The least in the kingdom of heaven
questions.correctAnswer: The least in the kingdom of heaven
questions.explanation: Jesus states that though John is the greatest born of women, the least in the kingdom of heaven surpasses him, pointing to the new covenant blessings surpassing the old (Matthew 11:11). This reflects the eschatological hope of the kingdom (Luke 7:28; Isaiah 9:7).

questions.question: How does Jesus describe the response of His generation to John and Himself?
options: Like children in the marketplace, calling to their fellows but rejected
Like faithful followers who accepted both
Like prophets who understood the signs
Like kings who welcomed their messengers
questions.correctAnswer: Like children in the marketplace, calling to their fellows but rejected
questions.explanation: Jesus compares the generation to children calling but not responded to, indicating their spiritual stubbornness and rejection of both John’s asceticism and Jesus’ fellowship (Matthew 11:16-17). This reflects prophetic lament themes (Jeremiah 6:10; Isaiah 65:2).

questions.question: In what way does Jesus contrast John the Baptist’s lifestyle with His own?
options: John came neither eating nor drinking; Jesus came eating and drinking
John was wealthy; Jesus was poor
John was a carpenter; Jesus was a fisherman
John lived in the city; Jesus lived in the desert
questions.correctAnswer: John came neither eating nor drinking; Jesus came eating and drinking
questions.explanation: Jesus contrasts John’s asceticism with His own sociability, highlighting differing ministry styles and the rejection both faced (Matthew 11:18-19). This contrast addresses objections to Jesus’ association with sinners (Luke 7:33-34).

questions.question: What judgment does Jesus pronounce upon Chorazin, Bethsaida, and Capernaum?
options: They will face harsher judgment than Tyre, Sidon, and Sodom for not repenting
They will be exalted in the kingdom of heaven
They will be protected from judgment because of their works
They will be destroyed by natural disasters soon
questions.correctAnswer: They will face harsher judgment than Tyre, Sidon, and Sodom for not repenting
questions.explanation: Jesus condemns these cities for rejecting His mighty works, stating their judgment will be more severe than notorious sinful cities, emphasizing accountability to revelation (Matthew 11:20-24). This aligns with prophetic warnings in Amos 3:2; Ezekiel 33:8-9.

questions.question: To whom has God revealed the truths of the kingdom according to Jesus’ prayer?
options: Babes and those humble in heart
questions.correctAnswer: Babes and those humble in heart
questions.explanation: Jesus thanks the Father for hiding truths from the proud and revealing them to humble ones, emphasizing divine sovereignty and spiritual humility (Matthew 11:25-26). This theme echoes Proverbs 3:5 and Isaiah 66:2.

questions.question: What exclusive knowledge relationship does Jesus describe between Himself and the Father?
options: No one knows the Son except the Father, and no one knows the Father except the Son
The angels know the Father better than the Son
The prophets know the Father but not the Son
All people know both the Father and the Son equally
questions.correctAnswer: No one knows the Son except the Father, and no one knows the Father except the Son
questions.explanation: Jesus teaches the unique mutual knowledge between Father and Son, affirming His divine identity and exclusive revelation (Matthew 11:27). This aligns with Johannine theology (John 10:30; Colossians 2:9).

questions.question: What invitation does Jesus extend to those who labor and are heavy laden?
options: Come unto me, and I will give you rest
Join the Pharisees for proper worship
questions.correctAnswer: Come unto me, and I will give you rest
questions.explanation: Jesus invites the weary to find spiritual rest in Him, highlighting salvation’s restorative nature (Matthew 11:28). This reflects Old Testament promises of rest in God (Psalm 23:1-3; Isaiah 40:31).

questions.question: How does Jesus describe His yoke compared to other burdens?
options: His yoke is easy, and His burden is light
His yoke is heavy like the law
His yoke is only for the righteous
His yoke is optional for believers
questions.correctAnswer: His yoke is easy, and His burden is light
questions.explanation: Jesus contrasts the oppressive burdens of legalism with the gracious yoke He offers, emphasizing His meekness and the spiritual rest He provides (Matthew 11:29-30). This echoes Jeremiah 6:16 and Psalm 55:22.

questions.question: Who does Jesus identify as 'Elias' who was to come?
options: Elijah the prophet from the Old Testament
A future prophet yet to come
questions.correctAnswer: John the Baptist
questions.explanation: Jesus identifies John as the fulfillment of the prophecy about Elijah’s return (Malachi 4:5), emphasizing John’s role in preparing the way for the Messiah (Matthew 11:14). This is confirmed in Luke 1:17 and Mark 9:11-13.

questions.question: What does Jesus say about the kingdom of heaven from the days of John the Baptist until now?
options: The kingdom suffers violence, and the violent take it by force
It has been completely peaceful and accepted
It is hidden and unknown to all
It is only for the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: The kingdom suffers violence, and the violent take it by force
questions.explanation: Jesus describes the kingdom’s advance amid opposition and spiritual conflict, indicating the intense struggle involved in entering God’s reign (Matthew 11:12). This reflects Old Testament imagery of spiritual warfare (Psalm 2; Daniel 7:25).

questions.question: What question does Jesus ask the crowds regarding their expectations of John the Baptist?
options: Did you go out to see a reed shaken by the wind?
Did you expect a king to come?
Did you want a priest to lead you?
Did you hope for a warrior to fight?
questions.correctAnswer: Did you go out to see a reed shaken by the wind?
questions.explanation: Jesus challenges the crowd’s perception of John, contrasting his steadfastness with a reed shaken by the wind, indicating John’s resolute prophetic character (Matthew 11:7-8). This is a critique of unstable faith (Psalm 1:3).

questions.question: How does Jesus describe John the Baptist in relation to a prophet?
options: He is more than a prophet
He is less than a prophet
He is not a prophet at all
He is equal to all other prophets
questions.correctAnswer: He is more than a prophet
questions.explanation: Jesus declares John to be more than a prophet, as the forerunner who fulfills Malachi's prophecy and directly prepares the Messiah’s way (Matthew 11:9-10). This surpasses the role of typical prophets (Isaiah 40:3; Luke 1:17).

questions.question: What does Jesus say about those who will not be offended in Him?
questions.correctAnswer: They are blessed
questions.explanation: Jesus pronounces blessing on those who are not offended by His ministry or message, highlighting the value of faith amidst potential stumbling blocks (Matthew 11:6). This aligns with blessings in Psalm 1 and James 1:12.

questions.question: What role does John the Baptist fulfill according to Jesus?
options: The messenger who prepares the way for the Messiah
A teacher of the law only
questions.correctAnswer: The messenger who prepares the way for the Messiah
questions.explanation: Jesus affirms John’s role as the prophesied forerunner who prepares Israel for Jesus’ coming, fulfilling Malachi 3:1 (Matthew 11:10). This is confirmed in Isaiah 40:3 and Luke 3:4-6.
